39409880.review:
Although KAMI is a mobile port with a clear mobile vibe to it still, its core puzzle mechanic is rock solid with a pleasantly clean and colourful presentation. The majority of the puzzles are relatively easy to solve and mainly serve to acquire and train useful strategies. The later puzzles, especially in the included premium section, can be ridiculously hard to perfect though.

The graphics consist of real photos of coloured paper and indicate a handmade surface texture with folding animations appearing like a haptic simulation. Appearance and sound form a theme around Japanese traditional culture and promote a relaxed puzzle environment. Since there's no time limit or other constraints, contemplating over individual moves can easily become an indulging experience lasting longer than expected.

Remnant of the mobile version is the hint credit system which allegedly is still limited in uses and bound to a daily reset. Playing without hints is arguably the better experience though, as figuring out the right move after a long time of thinking is the most satisfying reward in itself. Before taking wild guesses out of frustration it's definitely better to take a break instead.

KAMI's difficult solutions and beautiful aesthetics make it a great puzzle game.

Very relaxing puzzle that requires logical reasoning to understand how to spread colors through the table.

For a real challenge, try to complete each puzzle within the number of minimal possible moves.

A few final puzzles of the "Premium" level can be completed even with less than the minimal number of moves declared by the game.

I really enjoyed it and I recommend it to anyone interested in puzzles that require observation and development of a tactic.

Kami is of the best non-narative puzzle games I have played, it is both beautifully done in hand crafted paper and clever to the point of intrigue while not having any of the complex causalities that might make you sit there for hours on a singular puzzle.

The only thing I could see as being an issue to some is the aforesaid strategies never really diverge from one singular expansion eventually engulfing the board.  Whereas it could have easilly had a more diversified outlook and had puzzles that require multiple fronts of attack that would require possible mapping if not just more complex problem solving, the slightly more straight forward method most definitely encourages an intrensic motivation that keeps you entranced on the colours at hand (or patterns as is the case in one absolutely beautiful collection).

It is simple to understand, erudite to the point of eloquence, and holistically beautiful ; I swear I heard bamboo flute music playing in the background...and not just the bamboo flute music that was the actual sound track...

Occasionally you come across a game which makes you so happy that you discovered it, that you want to meet the developers and just say thank you. Well here is your chance http://www.stateofplaygames.com/about-us/

Kami is the name given to the type of paper used in Origami. Essentially in each puzzle you’re presented with a colourful board filled with different coloured squares of Kami and your objective is to fill the board into a single colour using the shortest amount of moves possible. It might sound easy and some of the puzzles are, but as you progress your brain will definitely be challenged. There are no time requirements, no penalties for using the hint system and with the help of calming visuals and sound your time spent in this game will simply be a underwhelming satisfying puzzle Zen experience.

There are 45 Classic Kami Puzzles to solve and 17 that slightly alter the concept of the board that you’re usually presented with in the premium category. While the game remains simplistic in its terms it achieves so much more than other games by delivering to the gamers something fresh, something unique and something that remains in harmony and loyal to its core theme, an attractive aesthetic puzzler that aims to relax.

32954562.review:
[i]Kami[/i] is a minimalist puzzle game, with a simple mechanic and a typical mobile interface. The goal of every puzzle is to get the board to a single color in the fewest number of moves.

Kami ramps up appropriately, exploring various types of boards and helping you figure out new tricks and strategies. The puzzles are a nice blend of thinking through conceptually (what strategy should I use in deciding where to click?) and just clicking somewhere to see what happens. The puzzles can get fairly difficult, forcing you to change your plan of attack when it isn't working. Only one puzzle felt completely impossible; I tried it for an hour after beating the rest of the game but  finally gave up and used the hints. At the other end of the spectrum, maybe 30-50% of the puzzles are very easy, requiring one or two attempts.

Except for the level I couldn't solve, perfecting all the levels took about 7 hours. This is long enough to include a substantial amount of content, but not so long for the levels to feel repetitive or tedoius.

The atmosphere, graphics, and experience are smooth, with care put into the details. For example, the game allows you to click again while one click is still playing out -- this is really a no-brainer, but too many games don't have such features.

Cons: First, I would have appreciated some steam achievements for the game. Second, at least two later levels were solvable in fewer moves than the "perfect" solution; I personally would have appreciated the extra challenge. Finally, there is the minor annoyance that pressing ESC puts the game into small windowed mode instead of quitting (I'll get used to it).

KAMI is simple and satisfying puzzle game. Game idea is very simple: click to change from one color to another all touching same color squares and in the end you have to make all field to same color. There isn't anything too complicated in the KAMI what makes it even more enjoyable and nice. 

[h1] PROS [/h1]

[b] Satisfying. [/b] The way colors changes (unwraps like origami) is really staisfying and nice. It gives you feeling that everything is in order and there is no chaos between you and the game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=913675909

[b] Graphics. [/b] KAMI graphically looks really nice and there is no distractions anywhere. Developers didn't tried to overdo leavining game looking simple but beautiful.

[b] Soundtrack. [/b] This game is relaxing and music just adds peace in the game. There is no tension anywhere and music hit the mark. Even though KAMI is puzzle based game I felt relaxed and calm after playing it.

[h1] NEUTRAL [/h1]

[b] Gameplay. [/b] Yes everything is calming and peaceful but there could be more in the gameplay. There is only 1 type of mechanics used in game and nothing more. At least there could be blocks that does different things (double colored, block that can't change color).

[h1] CONS [/h1] 

[b] Levels design. [/b] Yeah levels design felt repetetive to me and some of levels looked very similar even though they palyed out differently still it gave feeling of repetition.

[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1] 

I recommend to play KAMI for everyone feeling angry or bad in general because this game will make you feel more comfortable and relaxed. This game can be played by few minutes sessions and you won't forget how it is played because of simple mechanics.

30858489.review:
Petit jeu, petit retour.

Encore un jeu de casse tête, ça doit être ma marotte du moment, mais lui m'a pris par surprise: des feuilles de papier de couleurs s’entremêlant qui n'ont d'autre but que d'être unifiée dans une seule couleur ... c'est un jeu communiste ?

Un grand silence pendant les parties, seul le doux bruit du papier qui se froisse vient détendre le cerveau trituré qui cherche à résoudre le bordel devant ses yeux ... à la limite d'une vidéo ASMR, c'est réellement relaxant ce jeu.

De la simplicité des premiers tableaux aux déchirement neuronal des derniers, chaque partie est un petit plaisir, qui se savoure sans limite de temps (tant mieux). Le seul gros défaut (et qui a été ajouté après la sortie apparemment) est la saloperie de musique (impossible à supprimer) 2* 15 000 Watts qui vient conclure ... non, qui vient détruire les tympans après chaque puzzle résolu.

Il y'a une partie casse tête normaux (avec difficulté croissante) et une autre avec des casse tête plus corsés MAIS avec des motifs différents. Autant le jeu avec des couleurs est très simple, autant le même jeu avec des motifs bizarres rend le tout plus illisible que compliqué, c'est dommage ... mais pour ceux qui n'ont pas peur de se fracturer un œil, ça se tente.

Dans tous les cas ce jeu est une tite perle de douceur dans le monde des casse tête, je conseille. ^^

Kami è un gioco molto leggero, per i fieri possessori di  un tostapane, che inizialmente nacque come titolo per cellulari, poi successivamente venne adattato e reso disponibile anche su PC.

La formula del gioco è abbastanza semplice: in ciascun livello abbiamo dei quadratini di carta con diversi colori e lo scopo è quello di rendere tutti i quadratini di un solo colore nel minor numero di mosse possibili.
Il gioco è tutto qui, va preso come per chi ha voglia di rilassarsi e allo stesso tempo spremere un po' le meningi tra un gioco serio e l'altro.
Graficamente è piacevole, è stata usata della carta vera per renderizzarla, dando così la sensazione che a ogni nostro click stiamo davvero piegando della carta.
Purtroppo, il gioco dura un paio di ore e una sua grossa pecca è l'assenza di musica durante i livelli, per cui dopo un po' magari, ad alcuni potrebbe dare fastidio il fruscio della carta che si piega. In tal caso suggerisco di sopperire a tale mancanza con una playlist di musica rilassante.

23422029.review:
The thumb down here, is more a critic as a not recommendation.

The type of this puzzle itself is excellent!
You fill paper fields with color, trying to fill the whole screen with one color at last.
The animations and the SoundFx makes this so awesome.
In this game you use your visual imagination and recognize relationships between colors and pattern.
There is no understanding of numbers needed. 

But the implementation is unfortunately the worst on this game.
-  Music: One asiatic sounding loop, that playing in the background. 
+ Music: You can turn it off ;D
-  No learning curve. It is more try and error at some puzzles. At the end of the game it feels easy again -.-
+ Hints:  Everyday you get new credits to unlock new hints.
-  Hints:  You need use the hints before the puzzle and if you unlock more hints, so do what they really show, or you will miss the following hint.

23059940.review:
Das Ding ist ein Rätselspiel pur. Kein Schnickschnack, nichts außergewöhnliches. "Nur" ca. 60 Rätsel folgender Art:

Ein Spielfeld aus farbigen Kästchen muss in so wenig wie möglich Zügen einfarbig werden. Pro Zug wird das ausgewählte Kästchen und alle gleichfarbigen anliegenden Kästchen mit der aktuellen Farbe gefüllt. Fertig. Das wars und kann doch ziemlich schwer werden.

Der Tag "Entspannung" fand ich allerdings fehl am Platz. Meditativ fand ich daran nichts, es sei denn, auch "Talos" oder "Portal" empfindet man als entspannend und meditativ.

Das Spiel beginnt, und das ist gut, mit ganz einfachen Aufgaben und steigert sich dann ganz erheblich. Ich hätte nicht gedacht, dass es so schwierig werden kann, eine optimale Lösung zu finden. Hinterher (ist man klüger, ich weiss) ist mir klar, dass man auch bei diesem Rätseltyp die Schwierigkeitsstufe beliebig steigern kann, dass keiner mehr mitkommt. Um es kurz zu machen, ich habe nicht alle Rätsel lösen können (aber die meisten, immerhin).

Die Musik ist tatsächlich nervig, aber ich schalte sie eh' ab, um mich konzentrieren zu können.

Ein Kritikpunkt von mir ist, dass in einer Gruppe der Rätsel die Schwierigkeit dadurch erheblich gesteigert wird, dass statt Farben gleichfarbige, unterschiedliche Muster verwendet werden. Das empfinde ich als Unfair-Play (weil aus einem Logik-Rätsel eine visuelle Herausforderung wird). Zum Glück sind dies nur 9 der ca. 60 Rätsel.

Pro & Contra:

+ Gute Rätsel

o Muster statt Farben bei einigen Rätseln

- Nervige Musik

Wertung: 09/10

Das Spiel liefert was ich mir erhoffte: gute Rätsel. Also ist das Spiel gut. Aber 4 Euro? Da hab ich zum Glück im Sale zugegriffen. Dann ist das Preis-/leistungsverhältnis in Ordnung.

21678136.review:
KAMI, how I deigned to love thee. Your puzzles were sweet, and your style was grand. How that sitar swooned me in the gentle february nights when I got perfects left and right. It wasn't until the third set of puzzles that I learned of your vile transgressions against me.

10 hint credits a day, with no way to earn more. "No matter," I said. "These puzzles will not conquer me, for I am one with the kami." Oh, but sweet KAMI, I was wrong. So wrong. Your puzzles became devious, and your sparse, archaic mobile-style hint system with the only ability to wait for the timer to run down for my next set, in which I would use oh so sparingly. I needed my approving sitar, my golden perfect.

Our peaceful days did not last. When in the deep of a puzzle, some where over a dozen flawless moves needed to be made, I discovered yet another transgression: no rewind button, only reset. The peace was over, and the fear of using too many hints drove me quite mad. Many times I would be a breath away from perfection, only to squander a certain move and have to start from scratch once more. Gruelling. Your cold beauty drove a steak through my puzzle loving heart.

The puzzles too, they withered in scale. No more were the clever patterns or cute little shapes, just guessing, guessing which color to start with, which amorphous shape to expand from. The challenge was gone, yet the frustration lived on. Oh KAMI, you could've been a classic, but you failed your own tenets of relaxing challenge and squandered your greatest assets as a thoughtful puzzler.

KAMI, you really are quite something, but the people should know of your faults as well. You're definitely worth a grab in a sale, but regretably not much more.

21325276.review:
Das Spiel „Kami“ basiert auf Origami, der alten Kunst des Papierfaltens. Deine Aufgabe ist es farben- und musterbasierte Rätsel dadurch zu lösen, dass einzelne Teilflächen des Rätsels in ihrer Farbe verändert werden bis die gesamte Fläche einfarbig ist. 

Zunächst scheint Kami sowohl optisch als auch mechanisch ein recht simples Spiel zu sein, jedoch findet sich seine Schönheit in eben dieser Einfachheit. Die Farben des in den Rätseln verwendeten Tonpapiers sind lebendig und das Papier selbst ist fotorealistisch. Die Animationen sind glatt, Einzelstücke drehen und falten sich ansehnlich in die ausgewählte Farbe. Bei großen Flächen erzeugen diese Änderungen eine Art Kaleidoskop-Effekt.

Musikalisch erinnert Kami an ein chilliges China-Restaurant; fast kann man die Köche in der Küche schreien hören. Die Musik lässt sich insgesamt und insbesondere auch während der Rätsel an- oder ausschalten. Die Geräusche beim Falten des Papiers sind kräftig und effektvoll. Man spürt förmlich das Papier zwischen den Fingern.

Es gibt drei Möglichkeiten ein Rätsel zu beenden: 
mit einer perfekten Punktzahl,
mit einem  Okay, 
oder einem Fail. 

Eine perfekte Punktzahl wird erreicht, wenn die Anzahl der Änderungen zum Erreichen einer einfarbigen Fläche in der vom Spiel vorgegebenen Anzahl an Zügen erreicht wird. Ein Okay ist mit der perfekten Anzahl der Spielzüge plus einem Spielzug erreicht. Alles andere ist ein Fail. Solltest Du in einem der Teils knackigen Rätsel stecken bleiben, kannst Du ein Hinweis-System nutzen.

Kami ist trotz seines Zen-ähnlichen Aussehens kein besonders leichtes dafür aber ein spielenswertes Rätselspiel. Folglich empfehle ich es jedem der gerne rätselt oder auch denjenigen die ihren lokalen Asiafood-Store zu schätzen wissen. Kami ist im Sale regelmäßig für unter 1 Eurone zu haben.

Zunehmend tricky sind  die Lösungen "perfekt" zu meistern. Besonders durch das einzigartige Design ein gelungenes Game mit Entspannungsgarantie. 21294462.review:
[h1][b]「Origami killer」[/b][/h1]

[b]KAMI[/b] - ещё одна жертва беспощадного конвейера мобильного рынка, на котором приянто давить покупателя не качеством, а количество. Конечно, ни одна из современных игровых платформ не застрахована от наплыва второсортных и низкокачественных продуктов, но нигде как на мобильных девайсах им уделяют больше всего внимания, ведь рядовой пользователь пользователь тких платформ человек подвижного образа жизни, которому некогда проходить многоуровневые подземелия в каком-нибудь фентези-РПГ. Немногочисленные серьёзные продукты и порты со старших собратьев - редкое исключение, большая часть магазинов всё равно забита однотипными погремушками, которые, несмотря на свою коммерческую успешность, не могут предложить ничего кардинально нового и использующих ровно одну и ту же механику из года в год. Разгребать подобный хлам скудоумной мысли с каждым годом всё труднее и труднее, а найти в этой куче хоть чего-нибудь мало-мальски отличающееся от прочего контента - еще то удовольствие. Очевидно, что и [i]State of Play Games[/i] не сделала ничего из ряда вон выходящего, а просто (в какой уже раз?) переделала на свой лад банальный геймплей десятилетней давности, оценить который можно опробывать абсолютно [u]бесплатно[/u] в какой-нибудь флеш-поделке. Зато ещё раз подтвердили, что нынешний потребитель весьма непритязателен в выборе себе хорошего развлечения - отсюда и место в топах продаж, и положительный рейтинг и хвалебные отзывы.

[i][u]Фальшивый герой...[/u][/i]

Однако, забавнее станосится уже от того, что своей [b]KAMI[/b], [i]State of Play Games[/i] загородила не только множества более достойных проектов, но и свои же собственные творения. Те же куда более примечательные [b]Lumino City[/b] и [b]Lume[/b] привлекли к себе меньше внимания, чем простая до безобразия "расскраска оригами" под скудный звуковой ряд.

За ровно эту же сумму в Steam можно приобрести [b]Strata[/b] - которая гораздо приятнее внешне, интереснее и имеет в довесок игровые достижения.

[u][b]Рейтинг:[/b] [i]Бесполезный оригами...[/i][/u]

20992574.review:
This game is aesthetically pleasing. The art goes very well together with the sound design, which is mostly the sound of folding paper, but they got that one just right. Solving the puzzles means a lot of folding, but the sound and visuals never became repetitive, instead they give a constant sense of satisfaction at your progress. More importantly they don't distract you from solving the puzzles and remain a backdrop. The game also allows you to turn off the music, making contemplating the puzzles a smooth calming experience. 

Of course you don't play a puzzle game for the design, but to tickle your brain and at that KAMI excels. You will use your intuition and structural analysis to determine the optimal solution. The designers got the puzzle progression and the learning curve just right as I felt my skills improving until the very end of the game. As to the last and longest premium puzzle (3-9), I found a weak spot, finished it in 18 moves instead of the perfect 19 on my first try and was like "meh". In hindsight I see that means a very well designed puzzle(game).

At other times though, you won't see the solution, you won't get lucky and you will simply have to guess. And KAMI enables that. Restarting the puzzle and trying out other ideas are part of the gamedesign and feel natural. You are meant to do that - a lot. Sometimes trying out random things is even required before you start seeing any patterns.

There are two possible outcomes for each puzzle: the perfect solution (smallest amount of moves necessary to finish the puzzle) and an OK solution (perfect + 1 move). Any more than that and you fail - which obviously bears no consequences other than your increasing frustration. The amount of moves required is shown next to the puzzle, so you will know how well you are doing. The puzzles are meant to be finished with the perfect score, the OK solutions rarely require an eureka moment, which doesn't mean they are easy, but they definitely aren't a challenge. Even the sound the game makes after an OK solution says: "At least you tried. Guess this will have to do." You can also have the game drop a limited amount of hints, though I don't recommend it, as there aren't many puzzles to begin with.

This brings me to the game's faults, of which there aren't many. Mostly, it is simply too short (which is of course only my subjective opinion). There are only 72 (45 regular + 27 premium) puzzles and the replay value is very small once you've found the perfect solutions, though with some premium puzzles you might want to examine your newfound solution in more detail. What is more, as you progress, the earlier puzzles become laughably easy. It took me about 8 hours to get everything I can out of this game.

Furthermore, the second set of premium puzzles (one set is 9 puzzles) which uses abstract symbols instead of colours feels completely unnecessary. The difficulty is artificial and comes from the player having a hard time discerning between the markings. I would appreciate the change in visuals if it was well done. Alas, it is not and the puzzles in the second set are of little value.

Some useful information to new players: it is possible to complete premium puzzles 3-5, 3-6, 3-8 and 3-9 in less moves than required for a perfect solution. It feels actually pretty sensible as they are somewhat tough to begin with and there is no real reason to punish the player for not finding the very bestest of solutions.

All in all I would definitely recommend getting this game for full price or on sale. A unique gem.

Kami=Paper

It involves some more backward thinking, single tiles being the difference between a Perfect and Okay, or Okay and Fail as you have an alotted amount of moves to clear the board without failure. 19944137.review:
Kami (Paper) is a pleasing and well thought out puzzle game easily worth it's asking price - especially when it's on sale. The gameplay is simple yet challenging; the goal being to convert the entire board into a single colour of paper within an alotted amount of moves. The amount of puzzles is quite large (20+ levels that contain 9 puzzles each) and they increase in difficulty over time by adding more colours of paper and through making denser shapes with them.

There are hints available to help with puzzles you're struggling with; however they are rationed daily to prevent you from rushing through the game unjustly; which I found enjoyable as it forced me to sit down and examine pieces for longer - which in turn increased my apprecation of the delicate nature of the design. 

My only wish is that the thematic music (traditional japanese accents) was looped, or had a several tracks to move through. Currently the only music played is when the game is opened or when a puzzle is completed in the correct manner. These little tunes help encourage the setting intended by the designers, so it would have been nice to have more of the same - and with an option to mute or not (there is currently no mute function, meaning that if you put your own music on and complete a puzzle the in-game tunes will still play (I would have probably bought the OST as a bundle too if it was available)).

But that's just a minor complaint honestly. If you want to have a relaxing time and feel like you're being mentally challenged in a pleasing and charming way, then please buy this game. If nothing else, it's nice to have in your library when you want some quiet time to either just have some light fun or to just zone out and relax (i'd also recommened putting on some chill or classical music whilst playing, it just makes all that much more pleasing).

19124744.review:
This is a short, beautiful game, that is both refreshingly simple and challenging.

Although the puzzles get tougher as you proceed, I found that they became oddly easier at the same time. This is partly because you'll learn out-of-the-box strategies to solve some puzzles, which will show up again in later stages. Some of the trick solutions were particularly devious and brilliant, and I would never have even guessed the opening move if it weren't for the hint system.

The way the game gives you hints is fair, while still making you work for it. I played anywhere from 10 minutes to an hour every day until I finished the game, and a good chunk of that time was spent staring at puzzles because I used all my hint credits for the day, and nothing I tried was working. Only to laugh when I saw what the solution was the next day.

A lot of puzzle games can be frustrating, but I found KAMI to be joyful and relaxing. It is definitely worth the price, and if it's on sale, don't hesitate.

5/5 sheets of colored paper

[h1]РАЗБОР ИГРЫ[/h1]
Несложная головоломка, что пришла к нам с мобильного рынка. Игра представляет из себя разноцветное поле, которое нам нужно окрасить в один оттенок. Мы можем закрасить в нужный цвет одну клетку и все смежные к ней того же цвета. Нужно перекрашивать одну группу клеток под цвет других, близких клеток, тем самым всё больше окрашивая поле в единый цвет. Сложность заключается в ограниченном количестве ходов. Если до серебренной награды догадаться легко, то ради золота придётся хорошенько поразмыслить.

Выглядит [b]KAMI[/b] как куча листов бумаги для оригами, что аккуратно разложили на столе. Каждая смена цвета сопровождается анимацией перегиба листов, оторваться невозможно.

А вот музыкальное сопровождение подкачало. На всю игру лишь один трек в японском мотиве и тот надоедает буквально за 10 минут.


[h1]KAMI - отличная казуальная головоломка. И пораскинуть головой есть где, и вызов игроку вполне хороший. При этом очень приятная внешне. Для фанатов казуальных игр это определенно "Стоит внимания"[/h1]

18871458.review:
通关撒花：神之折纸，游戏如其名。

普通关卡：A-E，每关9小关。高级关卡：1-3，每关9小关，其中2的图形对于密集恐惧症患者来说不是很友好。

基本操作：选择需要的颜色，点击折纸，最终在有限的步数内完成一整张同色的纸。可以比规定步骤多一步，评价会从完美下降成过关，追求全完美的话还是有点挑战的。

可以跳关进行，也可以重复进行，算是个打发时间的小游戏，无成就也无卡片，纯娱乐。

没有撤销上一步这种设定，只有重置，算是美中不足，因为后期步骤动辄十几步，重置之后从头再来有点麻烦。

想完全靠运气通关是不可能的，这游戏需要观察规律和对色彩的敏感度。最重要的是，在后期复杂的图形中，需要找准一个突破口，连点成线再成面，才有可能在规定步骤内完成。

有人说这游戏类似LYNE，但是其实完全不一样，这游戏单看形式的话比LYNE复杂多了，尤其对色彩不敏感的人来说，简直眼花缭乱。

游戏自带提示，但每日次数有限制，尽量自己先想想，完全靠提示就不好玩了。

人民币结算开始以来入的首作，认真玩了一天，推荐。

------总结------
+整体气氛不错

中立项：BGM太少（一首），可能有的人就是喜欢这样简简单单的吧……

适合人群：休闲放松党  |  小型解谜游戏迷  |  极简画风党

17820991.review:
As someone who dislikes many forms of puzzle games, I can't say that Kami is a game within my interests. Still, since it had a very unique aesthetic, I decided to give it a go.

Visually, I've got nothing to add. The game is beautiful, and it also fits the general aesthetic. The music is also good, enhancing the aesthetic, but not much in terms of immersion or gameplay... to me, anyway. Still, it's cool!

The puzzles are my problem. The first puzzles, I enjoyed! They were elegant, simple, and could still twist your brain a bit, when you found out that the most obvious solution wasn't the most efficient. I liked that. 4-6 moves was cool. The puzzles were also visually well put together! It's a gimmick, but it's well made nonetheless.

The problem, for me, comes with later puzzles, where the patterns turn into chaos, and moves going as far as 19. Without hints, there are waaaay too many possibilities with very few seams where one could start. (I'm mentioning the last level) Thankfully, the hint system helps a lot! It's also limiting, since you have a daily limit for it... Roots from mobile, I guess. One hint per level, later on, is ideal, since at least you know where to start. 

All in all, it's just not my type of puzzle. There doesn't seem to be any real algorithm to solve it, and there barely are rules of approximation, later on. Initially, yes, sure. But later on, the levels are too chaotic for my taste. It's a matter of patience, at that point. 

The levels have 2 solutions. One, is perfect, with the given number of moves. The other one, is "ok", where you have ONE additional move. It's impressive how much of a difference that one move makes!
Perhaps it proves how ingenous the game can be. It's just not for me. It's like sliding block puzzles. I hate those!

The concept is simple, and it starts well! If it seems up your alley, go ahead! It's just not for me.

The premium levels (free on this version!) were a cool gimmick, but the middle set, in particular, had very obnoxious patterns. They were so similar that it was almost impossible to identify anything in the puzzle. The other were conveyed properly, though.


The solution is often awkward, not following any teaching of the game early on or anything. Good to pass the time, I guess.

17598748.review:
KAMI is a soothing little puzzle game.  It's pretty in a minimalist way with pleasant sound effects, although the limited music becomes grating quite quickly.

Mechanically it's simple but satisfying.  There's no progression of mechanics but there's a gentle and smooth difficulty curve, with puzzles building on what's been learned from earlier ones.  Puzzles are set out in groups of nine, but within those there are commonly subgroups of three puzzles which are increasingly difficult variations on a common theme.

On the whole I'd say the difficulty for puzzle fans is easy to moderate, although the last set of 'premium' puzzles (extra on the mobile version, included in the Steam version) are quite challenging.  After five hours' playtime I'm currently 98% complete - I have two of the 63 puzzles where I haven't hit the move budget - and I can't see there being any short-term replayability, but this is reflected in the relatively low price.

16787811.review:
This is how KAMI works:  Click on a square to assign it a new color, and all connecting squares of that color will change too.  Change it to the color of squares near that group, and you can change those squares next move too, as they're now the same color.  Do this until the whole area is one color.

There is a surprising amount of depth to the game, but I didn't have a lot of trouble with it.  Also, the last 9 "premium" (free expansion) levels seemed to be random garbage.  Even so on a couple of those levels I got UNDER the perfect score, which seems like it shouldn't be possible.  Maybe those levels weren't very polished.  I feel as though a bigger playing area could have added some needed challenge and enabled more varied puzzle designs.

It's very pretty too, but I wouldn't pay 4 bucks for this.  Get it on sale.

16663285.review:
KAMI is one of the best puzzle games I've played in a while. The concept is simple and the gameplay is challenging, which is right up my street. Add all that to the beautiful aesthetics and soundtrack, and you have yourself a near perfect game. Although the game is a little short, I have gotten 9 hours of fun (and, sometimes, frustration... and then relief upon finding the solution) out of KAMI so far, and I definitely see myself returning to it at some point. Well worth the price. 

My only real gripe is that the second set of the premium puzzles were much unlike the others, as instead of simple colours, the folded paper had harsh black and white patterns, which really hurt my eyes and made it difficult to focus on the screen, which meant I had to keep coming back to them later. I understand that the patterns were used to add to the difficulty, but it wasn't for me. 

Other than that though, the game is perfect (in my opinion, of course), and the level of difficulty is just about right. You can always aim for "OK" scores rather than "perfect" if the challenge is a bit much on some of the puzzles, but personally I love the challenge of solving the puzzle in the absolute minimum number of moves. I definitely recommend KAMI and I look forward to trying other games created by State of Play.

15434582.review:
[h1]KAMI  纸[/h1]

二维 解谜 益智 视觉

[h1]概述[/h1]

这款游戏我相信对于大部分玩家基本是慈善包购买后全当加一了。
我在库中偶然看到这款游戏，随后尝试了一下，其实还是很具有趣味性的和挑战性的。
这款游戏不像别的游戏那样子需要大量的操作，娴熟的技巧。只需要安静下来，仔细观察。
基本上可以概括为：将屏幕上五颜六色的正方形纸片在有限的步骤下最终转变成一个颜色。

看到几十快上百个好友已拥有此游戏却大多数都毫无游戏时间记录，我相信他们认为LYNE只是一个工具，不是一个游戏吧。
有多少玩家购买LYNE是为了单纯解锁A~Z来拼自己的昵称，那就会有更多的人去无视这个游戏。
所以当你看到这个游戏时，我相信你也是不去试的。
“一天的负担那么重，谁有闲心去玩这游戏。”
“无聊的作品。”
基本也是这回复。
但这的确是一个不错的益智游戏。如果你喜欢益智游戏的话，为何不试一试这个呢？

[h1]Ins评分[/h1]

Steam适配 优秀

此游戏为单人游戏，推荐从慈善包入手。

Une ambiance zen, de jolies couleurs, un aspect papier origami atypique, un concept tout simple et pourtant un jeu casse-tête, voila comment se présente KAMI. 
Dans ce jeu il faut réussir à remplir une feuille avec des couleurs pour qu'au final celle-ci soit monochrome et tout cela en un nombre limité de coups.

15020785.review:
컨셉이 괜찮은 게임이다.
룰은 간단하니까 상점 페이지에 있는 영상을 한번 볼것.
이 간단해보이는 룰 가지고 적절한 난이도의 퍼즐을 만들었다는 거에서 가산점
비슷하게 아트뽕 내세운 'Strata'라는 게임보다 퍼즐적인 면에서는 훨씬 낫다.
올클하는데 4시간 조금 넘게 걸렸으니까 내 기준에서 가격 합당성도 만족 ($3.99)

하지만 퍼즐게임인데 스팀 도전과제를 지원하지 않고
무엇보다 프리미엄 퍼즐 2에서 점수를 왕창깎아먹었다.
프리미엄 퍼즐 2에서는 색종이 타일이 아니라 문양 타일로 바뀌는데 이거 9개 퍼즐 풀면서 눈아파 죽는줄 알았다.
시력 나쁜 사람들은 플레이 할 때 주의할 것.
프리미엄 퍼즐 3은 뭔가 끝판왕 같은 포스를 뿜었어야 했는데 3-7을 제외하고는 너무 쉬워서 이것도 단점.

이 모든 단점을 상쇄시킬만한 '신선한 퍼즐'게임이라는 거에서 추천.

I cut the music after some time after several hours as I'm playing it in between other stuff so it was an annoyance after some time. The sound at the end of a puzzle whatever you win or loose is way to loud and I didn't see any slider for that, even in windows it's at the minimum and still too loud.

I was playing strata before and it has too many puzzle, at the end I didn't felt the joy to finish each one as they were all the same. KAMI doesn't suffer from that in my opinion. The classic mode offer a large amount of different puzzle and the advanced mode give you some more, with the particularity of change the colour, which give quite a difficulty I think as it's tricking your eyes into error, I got of lot of fun doing those.

Hints system is good, but perhaps it's a bit much, if used on the same puzzle you can go up to 7 move on the 19 move last puzzle. But that one was crazy and I'm glad I had those helper. When I say tooo easy it's because you have 10 credits per day and the first hint cost 3, then it decreases. Even if it can feel cheating, on this game I didn't have that feeling, perhaps as I was unable to finish some of them and glad I could have an helper instead of looking for the solution ^^.

So I do recommend KAMI, for people who like puzzle game. It is a great fun.


PS: Do not pay attention to my number of hours spent on the game as I idled a lot on it.

Luuna.

14105142.review:
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/272040/]KAMI[/url] - Логическая игра.

Головоломка сделана в "бумажном" стиле, как будто мы играем в головоломку из бумаги. 
Головоломка состоит в следующем, изначально дан лист который заполнен разными цветами и в разных областях. 
Нам требуется сделать так что бы разноцветный лист был покрыт одним цветом. Для этого нам предлагается палитра из нескольких цветов. 
В общем манипулируя разными цветами нам требуется получить лист одного цвета, при этом есть определённое количество ходов которое нам отведено для этого. Если мы справляемся за отведенное количество ходов (или за меньшее количество ходов), то получаем золотую печать за решение. Если решаем головоломку и при этом превышаем (один-два хода) запланированное количество ходов, то получаем серебрянную печать.

По мере выполнения классического пака с головоломками, открывается доступ к премиум паку головоломок, который по идее, более сложный чем классический.

Так же в меню отображается % выполнения всех головоломок. И естественно что бы отображалось 100% нужно закончить все головоломки на золотую печать. 
И кстати в игре есть подсказки, всего в сутки можно посмотреть до трёх подсказок, после чего нужно будет подождать до следующего дня пока подсказки регенерируются.

В принципе игра интересная, но есть один существенный недостаток, это абсолютная линейность головоломок и их количество. Линейность это то что головоломки всегда одинаковые. Что касается количества, то классический пак состоит из 45 головоломок, а премиум из 27.

Дизайн приятный, звуки тоже, музыка не плохая (правда громкость не регулируется).

В целом игру рекомендую, но оценка не высока. Так как игра на одно прохождение. Ну и конечно, покупать ТОЛЬКО и ИСКЛЮЧИТЕЛЬНО по скидке.

Overall Score: 4 of 10.

[h1]Kami est un jeu de réflexion très soigné, plaisant à un prix très abordable[/h1]

La première des choses qui m’a plu chez Kami, ce sont les couleurs. Vous allez me dire que c’est un détail et pourtant, c’est ce genre de détail qui me fait souvent pencher dans un sens ou l’autre quand je dois me décider à acheter un jeu.

Il va de soit que je n’ai pas regretter cet achat. Kami est un jeu très soigné (graphiquement et musicalement) mais surtout très passionnant. Mon souhait pour ce jeu, et je sais que je ne suis pas le seul, c’est que les auteurs ajoutent des niveaux supplémentaires (du genre doubler le nombre de niveaux).

Tout le monde les aime mais personne n’ose l’avouer clairement. Mais où sont les succès et les cartes sur Kami ? Et bien, c’est malheureux, mais il n’y en a pas !

Pour le prix, si vous aimez les jeux de réflexion, Kami est un jeu à acheter absolument, vous ne le regretterez pas !!

KAMI is an attractive well-presented and simple puzzle game.  To solve each level you must select areas to fill continuously with a colour (like the paint bucket in MS paint), doing this a number of times to have the entire screen one colour to complete the level.

Highly original and learning curve is not steep.  Some later levels are very difficult however.

It doesn't take too long to make your way through a majority of the levels, so game-length is perhaps shorter than most similar puzzle games.  Some have compared it to LYNE which seemingly has no end.

Overall, recommended because it's a unique and refreshing take on the puzzle genre, well-presented and colourful.

Summary: Fun, very casual puzzles that are nice to wind down or relax with. But if you're looking for something very intensely engaging or a massive timesink, this is probably not going to be it. 

Pros: 
Very nice to look at whilst still being quite minimal in style.
Unique puzzles that make you think a little differently - to be precise, think very much in 2D. 
Relaxing - I like to play Kami when I want to zone out of work or at the end of the day. It's challenging enough to be engaging but not so addicting (for me, anyway) that you want to play it until 2am. At that late/level of tiredness you probably couldn't get anywhere with the harder puzzles anyway.

The music. I just switched it off, but then, it's just not my type of background music. It might be yours. 
This is a VERY casual puzzle game with no extras (other achievements besides 'Oh hey, you completed the level, here's the next one', or a story). It's part of its appeal but may also turn people off who are looking for something a little more exciting.

12273737.review:
KAMI to port gry dostępnej początkowo na iOS, przeniesionej zresztą potem także na Androida. Często słowa takie zwiastują produkt marny, będący skokiem na kasę ze strony twórców - na całe szczęście w przypadku omawianej tu pozycji tak nie jest, bowiem wersja PCtowa zawiera wiele ulepszeń w stosunku do swoich mobilnych braci, za co State of Play należy już na wstępie pochwalić.

KAMI oddaje do dyspozycji gracza 72 łamigłówki o różnym stopniu zróżnicowania. Sposób rozwiązania jest zawsze ten sam - doprowadzić do tego, aby na planszy pełnej różnokolorowych pól ostały się pola o jednym tylko kolorze przy użyciu określonej liczby ruchów (gra dopuszcza co najwyżej jeden dodatkowy ruch). Brzmi prosto? Cóż, niekiedy jest tak w istocie. Wraz jednak z podchodzeniem do kolejnych zagadek poziom trudności rośnie, a łamigłówki z trzeciej części paczki premium są już, a przynajmniej były dla mnie, bardzo trudne. Warto zauważyć, iż gra od razu udostępnia nam wszystkie z dostępnych zagadek, do których możemy podchodzić w wybranej przez nas kolejności - uważam to za bardzo sympatyczne rozwiązanie, dzięki któremu gracz nie jest skazany na męczenie się ze sprawiającą nadmierną trudność łamigłówką w celu uzyskania dostępu do kolejnych wyzwań.

Gra wpadła w moje ręce dzięki Humble Weekly Bundle: Eye Candy i nie jest przypadkiem, że tam się znalazła. KAMI jest bowiem pozycją bardzo estetyczną, zarówno pod względem grafiki jak i oprawy dźwiękowej. Graficznie gra prezentuje styl minimalistyczny, co dobrze współgra z prostymi założeniami gry, dopełniany przez proste i płynne animacje oraz delikatne azjatyckie akcenty. W azjatycki klimat wprowadza także spokojna i relaksująca muzyka.

No właśnie - KAMI to pozycja pozwalająca się odstresować, jednocześnie oferując wyzwanie dla szarych komórek. Niewiele gier potrafi zaoferować takie wyważenie poziomu trudności, które nie budzi irytacji, a jednocześnie wymaga od nas głębszego zastanowienia się nad rozwiązaniem stawianych przed nami problemów. Ta cecha gry w połączeniu z bardzo atrakcyjną oprawą wizualną i dźwiękową czyni KAMI unikalną grą logiczną w moich oczach, dlatego też polecam wszystkim zainteresowanym zapoznanie się z nią - aczkolwiek sugerowałbym poczekać, aż cena na jakiejś promocji spadnie do ok. 1 euro.

12143001.review:
Все гениальное - просто!
Kami (яп. бумага) - интересная, необычная и в то же время простая головоломка. Задача в каждом из уровней одна и та же - за определенное количество ходов превратить многоцветный листок бумаги, поделенный на маленькие квадраты, в одноцветный. Для этого мы должны перекрашивать зоны одного цвета в другой, зоной считается кусок бумаги, на котором есть квадраты одного цвета, соседствующие по вертикали или горизонтали (но не по диагонали). На словах это кажется куда более сложным, чем на деле - в игре ты схватываешь суть за 10 секунд. 
В игре есть несколько наборов головоломок, начиная от начального (5 блоков по 9 головоломок) и заканчивая несколькими дополнительными. Особенно понравился набор с черно-белыми узорами вместо обычных цветных квадратов - вначале я даже опешил от такого поворота =)
Название игры отлично описывает не только суть геймплея, но и весь стиль игры - Ками очень понравилась мне своим простым, как лист бумаги, оформлением. Опять же, это становится более понятным тогда, когда вы ее сами увидите.
Вообще игра больше подходит для мобильных устройств (собственно, с них она и пришла, как я понимаю), но это не значит, что она плохая. Наоборот, мне она очень понравилась, поэтому я могу смело рекомендовать ее любителям головоломок или просто тем, кто хочет поиграть в несложную, успокаивающую игру, в которой нужно немного пошевелить мозгами. 7/10

This is a pretty, minimalistic puzzler. You have a rectangular grid with squares painted in various colours and only one action - to repaint any contigous area into a new color. Given that, your goal is to have only one colour left on the board, and that in as few moves as possible. The first couple of levels are very easy, and then you are given more colours, and less obvious shapes on the board. But the difficulty progresses nicely, and there's a built-in hint system if you are stuck.

Actually, playing this with a mouse seems a bit inadequate, this is a perfect game for touchscreen devices. And it is - go and play it on your phone or tablet. It's also a perfect choice when you only have 15 minutes to play. As well as pretty enough and innocent enough to fool someone into thinking it's a wallpaper or some kind of screen-saver. So maybe office-safe too!

Go play it, it's worth your time.

11611660.review:
KAMI is a puzzle game centered around a very basic mechanic – you are given a field of colored squares. You can choose any color and change any other continuous section of squares into squares of that color. Your goal is to change the entire field of squares into a single color (though it can be any color) within a limited number of moves.

Story

	As a pure puzzle game, there is no story to this game.

Gameplay

	There are no real twists to the gameplay; every level in the game operates identically. Your progress is measured in how many moves it takes for you to succeed; if you complete a stage in the minimum number of moves possible, you get a “perfect” grade for the stage, and if you take one extra move, you get an OK grade. If you take two or more moves more than the minimum number of moves, you fail. You can restart each stage at any time, and three times per day, you can get a hint, which simply tells you what the first move in the puzzle is.
	 There are 9 stages in each “set” of stages, and 8 sets of stages overall, for a total of 56 stages. The stages start out fairly easy, but get progressively more difficult, adding more colors and more complexity to the patterns, and requiring increasingly greater numbers of moves. Early on, the puzzles can frequently be solved in three moves; by the end of the game, the final set’s easiest puzzle requires 8 moves, and the hardest set requires a whopping 19 – the initial “pattern” on many of these later puzzles looks almost like a random set of squares.
	The closest thing to a “twist” the game throws at the player is a single set of puzzles which uses black and white patterns on the squares in the place of the colored squares used in all the other puzzles; unfortunately, while it looks somewhat pretty, it makes the game harder primarily via interface screw, namely making it more difficult to tell which squares have which pattern.
	Oddly, there are a few puzzles in the game where the so-called “perfect” score isn’t; there are a few puzzles where it is, in fact, possible to actually beat the “perfect” score. Whether or not this is intentional is hard to tell, though it doesn’t really detract from the experience; it is just an oddity.

Graphics

	The game actually looks very nice and clean; the colored squares appear to be made out of construction paper, and the patterned squares have a very aesthetically pleasing visual appearance as well. The entire game’s user-interface is very straightforward and easy to use, though the “get a hint” system is somewhat strange in that hints cost three “points” to use and you get ten points per day – meaning that you end up with an extra, leftover useless “point” if you use up all your hints for the day.

Final Summary

	As a mobile game, this is a fairly reasonable choice; it is ideally suited for a touch interface, and the games are quite short, with the puzzles taking only a few minutes to solve each. Unfortunately, as a PC game, it is fairly lacking; it is not a very substantive experience, and while it is “enjoyable” in the same sort of way that solving a Sudoku puzzle is, it isn’t especially entertaining, and similar levels of entertainment can be found for free on the internet. There isn’t anything wrong with it; it just isn’t a very fulfilling experience.

11595174.review: I bought this game in a bundle, thinking it was just another silly puzzle game which could be accomplished in a matter of a couple hours. Well, not having anything to do, I started it up and was very surprised at what I got. The object of this game is to turn all the tiles one solid color. The trick is that the tiles you change will stop when they hit another color. For example, let's say there are two sides, red and blue, you turn one of the sides into the other by clicking on the side with the other color, solved. However, if there is a black tile in the blue zone, when turned red, every tile will turn except those behind the black tile, not being the same color. The visuals are fairly nice, limited but nice. The music is very nice, a calming, simple tune which is pleasent to hear. I will say that in the puzzles it is turned off. I found out just now by exploring that you can keep it on during the puzzles. Simply going to the options menu via a button, which I thought was a credits screem, will give you that option. The only negative, aside from that which is a nitpick, is that this game features two sets of puzzles: Classic and Premium. The classic puzzles are very enjoyable, increasing in difficulty but never very difficult, just hard enough. The same cannot be said for the premium puzzles. These start out fairly difficult and you will probably need a hint or two to progress. That's not a problem but the way this game handles hints, you'll run out of points easily and will need to wait about twenty-four hours before you go back to 10 hint points (which are spent as such, hint 1-3, hint 2-2, hint 3-1, hint 4-1, and so on). To end this review, for four dollars, you cannot go wrong so pick it up!

11416545.review:
English (Polska wersja niżej)
Kami is a relaxation puzzler (as opposed to ‘I will grind your brains into the dust and make you weep under the table’ puzzle games) ported from the mobile devices (without much harm done to the experience as it sometimes happens to mobile-to-pc games). The player is given a palette of 3-5 colors and is required to ‘paint’ the areas on the screen, so that they all should have the same color in a limited number of moves. 

I was able to complete the ‘standard’ puzzles in exactly two hours. There are 5 ‘seasons’, each of 9 riddles, which gives an average time of 2 mins per puzzle – that means they are rather on the easy-to-plain-effortless side . There is also a hint system available, but as far as the ‘standard’ puzzles are concerned, it is not really needed that much.     

The visuals of Kami are the very definition of ‘oddly satisfying’. Watching how screen fills with one particular color and listening only to the sound of paper folding is a pleasant and calming experience. This is probably the game’s greatest asset: it is a perfect  choice for unwinding after a tiresome day, and as far as I am concerned, it’s enough to make me return to the ‘premium’ puzzles (although, keep in mind that the 2nd ‘season’ –out of 3-  of ‘premiums’ deals with black and white patterns rather than colors, which makes it EXTREMELY difficult  to discern)   and wait for the sequel.

PL

Kami zalicza się do gatunku gier logicznych przeniesionych z mobilnej platformy – w tym przypadku bez szkody dla samej gry, jak to czasami się dzieje przy portach ze smartfonów. Kami jest przyjemnym i odprężającym doświadczeniem – nie stara się przemielić mózgu gracza ani sprawić że będzie płakać pod stołem przez resztę wieczoru bo tego puzzla się po prostu nie da…
 
W samej grze dostajemy paletę 3-5 barw i naszym celem jest ‘pomalowanie’ całego ekranu na jeden kolor w ograniczonej ilości ruchów.
 
‘Standardowe’ puzzle ukończyłem w dokładnie 2 godziny, 5 ‘sezonów’, każdy mający 9 zagadek – średnio wychodzi 2 minuty na puzzla, czyli podchodząc do Kami nie należy się spodziewać zbytniego wyzwania. Na marginesie wspomnę że dostępny jest system podpowiedzi, ale raczej się nie przydaje. 

Od strony graficznej Kami jest totalnie odprężającym doświadczeniem. Gapienie się w ekran zapełniający się stopniowo jednym kolorem najzwyczajniej w świecie uspokaja. Podobnie jak muzyka domyślnie grająca tylko w menu – ale można ją włączyć także do puzzli. 

Podsumowując: największą zaletą tej gry jest to jak pomaga złapać oddech po męczącym dniu. W mojej opinii to wystarczająca rekomendacja i najprawdopodobniej wrócę do sezonów ‘premium’ – choć trzeba ostrzec że w jednym z nich zamiast kolorów, mamy do czynienia z czarno białymi wzorami które straszliwie trudno rozróżnić. Niemniej, jeżeli kiedyś pojawi się kontynuacja, prawdopodobnie będę chciał się z nia bliżej zapoznać.

11171392.review:
An aesthetically beautiful and refreshing puzzle game that I found to be very challenging, but at the same time very relaxing due to the soothing sound and the simplicity of the visuals. The puzzle mechanics themselves are also quite refreshing and fun to play with, especially once I got used to them and could sometimes perfect new puzzles pretty quickly.

It's a very rewarding game and one that's almost impossible for me to get frustrated with, because of how beautiful and calming it is. As the description of the game says, I did find myself in deep contemplation several times, but there was very little to no stress for me, since there is no timer and you don't have to perfect everything to move on (even though I personally did want to perfect everything, being a perfectionist). 

Admittedly I haven't played too much of this game before writing this review, having only completed the A and B stages of the game so far (18 puzzles), but I think I got enough of a taste of this beautifully crafted game to recommend it to pretty much anyone. It's a joy to play.

Edit: I have now played Kami for a substantial period of time, and my esteem for it has only grown.

You should probably spend more than ten minutes on a game before you recommend it, or write a review, but I never do what I should probably do, and I'm not planning on changing that just now. 

Anyhow... the game is a basic math-based puzzler, albeit a spatial form-based game as opposed to numeric form-based endeavor, all the same - if you like thinking, this game is fun. And if you are not sharp, it is likely fun, too, it just may take a bit longer to progress, but the game design allows for revision, so it ultimately teaches everyone up to the same level. I love it - as a mathlete, and as a fan of creative gaming.

Best endorsement I can say: I bought two more copies of the game within ten minutes of playing it, to be gifted to my girl and my brother. As a purchase decision, it is that easily a no-brainer, despite the cerebral content within. I hope you enjoy it as well.

11021727.review:
Kami is serene yet engaging. It combines a beautiful esthetic with simple efficacy puzzles to a very satisfying effect. The puzzles are easy to complete, but they present a challenge by encouraging you to use the fewest moves possible. I find myself doing the same puzzles multiple times because I am determined to find that perfect move set.

The visual style of Kami is simple and elegant. Using a combination of complementary colors, you strive to turn your puzzle into the singular hue of your choosing. With each click, squares of folded construction paper flow out from the selected location, slowly turning the puzzle into a satisfying uniformity of color.  The game does not restrict you to any specific move limits, and instead will continue to be playable well beyond the recommend move goal. This freedom allows you to simply play with the colors; folding and shaping your paper until your heart’s content.

Kami's music is a beautiful rendition in a traditional Japanese style. The game gives you the option to play the music during the puzzles or you can leave the music off and solve the puzzles in near silence. Aside from the music, the only sound during the puzzle is that of folding paper which accompanies each of your moves. This makes for a mesmerizingly tactile experience.

The simple design, beautiful colors, and comforting sounds add together to make an elegant and relaxing experience that calls to me at the end of a stressful day. For the measly price this game requests it would be a shame not to experience this little slice of peace and beauty.

9776585.review:
KAMI는 State of Play Games에서 2014년 초에 출시한 퍼즐 게임입니다. 본래는 모바일 게임으로 IOS, Android용으로 출시되었습니다만, Steam에도 Greanlight 제도를 통해 입점하였습니다. Indie Gala의 Supreme Bundle의 구성물로 올라온 적이 있었지요.

 KAMI는 모든 종이를 하나의 색상으로 통일하는 간단한 룰을 지닌 퍼즐 게임입니다. 원하는 종이타일 위에 선택한 색상을 클릭하면 사각거리는 특유의 종이소리와 함께 접혀나가면서 다른 색상으로 변하는 것을 통해 종래에는 하나의 색상으로 만드는 것이지요. 정해진 최소의 횟수만으로 성공하는 경우 노란스티커가 붙으며, 그러하지 못한 경우는 청회색 스티커가 위에 붙습니다.

 모든 색상을 하나로 바꾼다는 룰은 일전에 소개했던 Color Oil( http://etude87.tistory.com/131 )과도 같습니다. 다른 원조격의 게임이 있는지의 여부는 잘 모르겠습니다만, 일단 굳이 둘간의 선후를 따지자면 Color Oil이 보다 먼저 출시된 작품이므로 서로 영향을 받았다면 KAMI가 Color Oil의 영향을 받았을 겁니다. 서로간의 다른 차이점이라면 Color Oil의 경우 시작하는 지점이 정해져 있고, 시작점으로 부터 연결되는 방식으로 진행할 수 밖에 없는데 반해서, KAMI는 자유롭게 원하는 위치의 타일을 변경할 수 있다는 차이가 있습니다.

 게임에서 유일하게 단점으로 꼽아볼만한 것이 있다면 적은 볼륨입니다. 일부 스테이지의 경우 새로운 방식이나 룰에대한 학습을 위한 징검다리 같은 것들이었으므로 생각보다 많은 허수가 포함되어 실질적인 스테이지는 그리 많다고 보기 어려웠습니다.

 군더더기가 거의 없어서 깔끔한 디자인이 일품인 퍼즐 게임입니다. 가볍게 즐기기에 좋으므로 PC 버전은 유료버전만 있지만, 모바일 버전은 무료 버전도 제공하고 있으므로 관심 있으신 분이라면 한번 가볍게 즐겨보시길 권장합니다.

 더 자세한 내용은 블로그 포스트( http://etude87.tistory.com/141 )를 참고.

9539572.review:
Ma note : 5/10

En lançant ce jeu casual, j'avais dans l'idée que celui-ci allait m'offrir une approche ludique des origamis (renforcé par le fait que KAMI rime avec cet art japonais). En fait, ce jeu n'a aucun lien avec le pliage, si ce n'est l'animation qu'il propose en colorisant les cases. Le but est simplement de peindre un rectangle bariolé afin qu'il se transforme en une surface unicolore avec un minimum de "coups de pinceau". Bien que plaisant et simple, la monotonie de la tâche devient rapidement ennuyeuse.

Avec ce casse-tête, je n'arrive pas à trouver les solutions logiquement. C'est plutôt mon instinct et quelques tentatives erronées qui me guident afin de résoudre les différents problèmes. Le jeu indique en combien de coups minimum le niveau peut être résolu de façon idéale (Perfect)... un coup supplémentaire est accordé pour une réussite, au-delà c'est un échec.

Les casse-têtes sont répartis en deux groupes : "Les classiques" (45 niveaux plus ou moins faciles) et les "premiums" (27 problèmes plus ardus). J'ai terminé les classiques (avec un Perfect pour chacun) en un peu moins de 4 heures (sans utiliser les Hints) et j'ai juste commencé les suivants. Selon moi, la durée de vie du jeu est d'environ 7-10 heures. Je terminerai sans doute KAMI en y jouant un peu de temps en temps car, comme je l'ai indiqué plus haut, il devient un peu trop répétitif (malgré une ambiance plutôt zen) et je commence déjà à m'en lasser.

9510513.review:
游戏的玩法非常简单，就是在三种颜色中选择一种颜色，可以把纸上一个区域的颜色全部染成指定的颜色，在规定步数内完成即可。但是玩法虽然简单，并不意味着难度简单。普通模式的那几关已经让我智商耗尽了，昨天洗澡的时候发现头发都掉了好多。

游戏的配乐也只有简单的几首，但是日本风非常优美动听。加上各种各样的折纸，看着也赏心悦目。

总的来说，是个素质非常不错的益智休闲小游戏。不过这游戏没有成就，也没有卡片。尽管页面上显示有23种语言，但是实际上游戏中根本没有文字没有语音，也没有语言选项。不建议特意全价购买，通过慈善包入手既可。

But, OH HELL, where to click, and when, and with what color.

This game generates a High Cognitive Engagement. 
This game prefers no age, gender, nor frag skill.

You picked up a sudoku book once. Admit it. So pick this up as well.

This is a very relaxing zen game. The music, the sound effects, everything about it is so nice. The algorithms are very complicated though, the game runs so smoothly. Each fold pattern goes so perfectly, I don't even know how it was coded.

That is from a programmers perspective, sorry. 

Basically, you have to fill the screen up with a certain color by selecting a color, and then filling a section. You have to try to solve the level in a certain number of moves (par). 

It is very easy at first, but after level 5, it starts to get a little hard. After you figure out the level, you say "How did I not figure that out 10 minutes ago?".

The game really makes you want to get a perfect score on each level. Get this game, it's awesome. Worth your money and time.

Grab a hot cup of green tea and start playing already!

8979440.review:
Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/kami-game-review/

KAMI is probably one of the more unique puzzle games that I’ve played as of late. The game has you folding paper, origami-style, to solve puzzles. The game’s title is the Japanese word for paper and I still have no idea how to pronounce it (I’ve been saying it like ‘CAM-E’).

The method used to solve each puzzle is why this game is so unique. Each puzzle starts you off with a square sheet of paper, much like origami, with this piece of paper being covered in small triangles of varying colors. Your objective is to make the entire sheet of paper one solid color in as little clicks as possible.  There’s a color palette at the bottom of each puzzle and its your choice in deciding what color the end result should be, with that hopefully being the color netting you the least amount of clicks.

When you click on any triangle in the puzzle, any other triangle of the same color connected to the clicked triangle will change into the color you have selected. This is a bit difficult to explain, so I encourage you to look at videos, etc. This color-changing mechanic is accomponied by a neat-looking animation as well, which I would describe as a sea of paper-folding triangles.

The game’s major fault lies in the amount of content offered. I wish there were more puzzles to do, as there’s only 63. The game is $4 (on Steam) though, so that may be the reason. I ran out of puzzles rather quickly, although that can probably be attributed to the fact that I went for the bare minimum ranking in each puzzle, “okay”, instead of opting to go for the “perfect” ranking in each. There is another ranking as well, known as “fail”, and I’m sure you can figure what that means on your own.

The game’s difficulty curve is fantastic. Slowly increasing, but not to a completely frustrating point. If you’ve got time to kill, then I highly recommend KAMI. Although it may be short, it’s well-worth the unique experience. Oh, it’s also worth mentioning that the game does not fully display in widescreen, but instead has some rather thin black bars to the left and right. No idea why it wasn’t optimized for widescreen, wish it had been.

8930128.review:
It's a lovely low-stress game with gorgeous visuals that looks beyond great on a Retina display.

My only complaint is that the level of difficulty is pretty low. Like some other reviewers, I finished in ~4 hours with a 100% perfect score. Part of that seems to be intentional - there are some clever sequences of 3 or 4 levels where each one becomes more difficult due to a few minor tweaks in the puzzle layout. These sequences effectively teach you how to excel at this game without any instruction but a gradual stretching of your intuition.

But it doesn't necessarily have to be quite so easy to master. The second premium level - with its eye-popping geometric papers that subtly subvert your efforts to visualize the pattern - hints at the kind of difficult-but-still-not-frustrating levels that would really make this game one to return to for many hours on end.

In addition, I found myself wishing that the paper folding mechanic was a more integral part of the game, As it is, it's just an admittedly gorgeous, mesmerizing way to fill up a space.

To sum up, don't take my criticisms too harshly...I am in a bit of tough love with this game. It has a sense of taste and elegance that is really rare in the gaming world, and we need more like it. It hints tantalizingly at the possibility of more difficult, but still dolorous and delightful, sequel. And I hope that the developers will soon satisfy that appetite for fiendish folding that they have provoked.

8892310.review:
While walking to your table, you've flipped your box of folding paper, your origami session is ruined!  But wait, they've landed in a pattern, isn't that interesting, what would happen if you just rearranged them a little?  In KAMI, you're given the chance to find out.

Puzzle games and brain teasers can be hard to properly quantify.  Is it a unique experience?  Is the game challenging?  Does it engage the player?  Does difficulty scale with skill?  Is it aesthetically pleasing and consistent?  Is it persistently replayable?  And when the player is done with a session, will they come away feeling satisfied?

KAMI is created by [url=http://www.stateofplaygames.com/]State of Play[/url], the makers of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/105100/]Lume[/url], and named for a [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origami_paper]folding paper used in origami[/url], it is a puzzle game where the user seeks to create a single homogeneous grid of paper by changing the patterns of sections of squares.  Each level has a series of different types of kami laid out in squares forming [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221844065 ]shapes and patterns[/url] on the play area.  When the player flips one piece of a particular kami, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221844167 ]all linked pieces of the same type also flip[/url], cascading in a way like what a player sees in game of go when a colour gets surrounded.

Reminiscent of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/61600/]Zen Bound 2[/url] for it's Asian aesthetic, KAMI is a very minimalist title without any intrusive elements to detract from it's core.  There is one audio track for the game, although not an unappealing one, it can therefore become a little repetitive.  It can be disjointing when the music abruptly halts as the player enters a puzzle, and equally abruptly begins when leaving one, no music plays while a puzzle is in progress.

KAMI is a puzzle game, so it will obviously not start your adrenaline pumping, and it won't shock you, but it will [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221903365]tug at your analytical brain[/url] and make you observe the grid and seek out patterns and layers of future moves.  Playing through KAMI you must see the effects of your moves often as far as 5 steps ahead in order to get a [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221844186 ]perfect score[/url] on a puzzle.  Once into the swing of things, getting an OK is not too hard, and often getting a perfect score will take a bit more effort, but not to the point of hair pulling or profanity.

The game revolves around finding a way to unite each different kami in [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221844101]successive order[/url], so if black touches all of the scattered reds then that is your first kami to flip.  Hints are available for those having a hard time with a particular puzzle, but you only get one hint per puzzle, and it is only the first flip of that puzzle, and while sometimes that will be enough to show a player what needs to be done next, sometimes it just isn't that [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221903418]straight forward[/url].

KAMI comes with the iOS version of the game's [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=221903449]premium content[/url], which considerably extends play time, but once completed, there is little to motivate a player to return to the game.  There are no achievements or leaderboards for the fastest completion time, no meta to the game.  It would have been nice for the developers to take advantage of online capabilities and the potential of an engaged player base by giving a puzzle creation tool to players, a remote server could store all user created puzzles, assigning them all lowest possible moves and letting players download new puzzles regularly.

Overall the experience is a calming and satisfying play through, with only a few minor caveats to interfere with the title.  I would say it's worth picking up for anyone who enjoys a sudoku session from time to time.  This review has been done in conjunction with Steam Contests, celebrating [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/contests]four years running[/url].

8850286.review:
Check out the full review at: http://www.youtube.com/BrbteabreakTV
http://youtu.be/ynLtLKQtRP0

In a recent review I talked about how simplicity is bliss and how games don't need to be doused in a thick layer of unneeded "features" in order to be amazing. Sometimes I want to play a game with no frills or strings attached and just enjoy myself, welcome to KAMI. KAMI is a very "simplistic" game with the goal of turning all the paper into a certain colour. 

This little game is quite deceiving, in a good way. Each level while having the same goal is completed in a completely different manner, though levels usually only have one solution if you want to get the perfect score, it cannot be helped though due to the simplicity of the colour scheme and how it's not based on some RNG element. You have to plan your moves 3-4 turns ahead and have to look at the big picture in order to achieve perfection. They're simple to complete, but challenging to perfect, and this balance keeps the game from becoming a chore and causing frustration.

Another thing to point out is this game is a port from the iOS, and from what I can tell not much has been changed. The menus cannot be navigated with the keyboard, it's not widescreen, lacks a decent options menu and also contains a weird hint system which seems to have been a microtransaction on the iOS.

In saying that it controls fine on the mouse and there seems to be no random mouse acceleration. It also can be played in a tiny window mode while still being fully playable, great for someone who experiences a lot of downtime at their PC. It will also run on Potato so you can just leave this running in the background without worrying about its hindereance on your PC's capabilities.

The music sticks to the Japanese theme of the game and helps maintain the mood without becoming to overpowering. Sadly the music does not play during the puzzles themselves, and while one might say it's to help concentration why not just give me the option to mute it during said puzzle? A simple icon would suffice to mute the soundtrack during gameplay.

It also goes without saying that KAMI looks amazing, animations are fluid and has a lot of subtle details that one might glance over. Things such as each paper square, though sharing a colour actually vary slighlty in texture or contrast. It has seemless transitions between all its game modes and puzzles, there's no loading screen which makes you think to yourself, just one more, just one more, and by then you've spent an hour looking at different colour paper and you've missed your bus.

While I've been beating down on the game a bit, it's still enjoyable and the things I've discussed are condiments to an already satisfactory meal. While short you're going to enjoy your experience and will be euphoria for anyone who loves to plan turns ahead, much in the way of a game like Chess. That said I would recommend picking it up on Android or iOS for $1, same experience but save yourself some money.

8838776.review:
This is a puzzle game played on labeled planar graphs.  On each move, you relabel a vertex, then merge it with any neighboring vertex with the same label.  The goal is to reduce the graph to a single vertex in the fewest possible moves.  Describing it in those terms doesn't sound as fun, but I find the puzzles are much easier to solve when considered as graphs instead of the pretty-but-extraneous 2D layout.

This is a mobile port, but works well on Windows 8 touch devices (I play on a Surface Pro 2).  The game initially shipped without a close button (don't need it on Android/iOS), but that was quickly remedied.  You will occasionally be asked to rate the game, but other than that there aren't any mobile problems.

39463785.review:
Genial juego de State of Play, al que acudí tras acabarme Lumino City y querer más de este estudio.
Este juego está centrado enteramente en los puzzles. El objetivo es sencillo: Convertir el área de juego, compuesta por cuadrados de diferente color, en un área de color uniforme. Al picar con un color sobre un cuadrado éste y todos los cuadrados adyacentes cambian a ese color. De este modo, se van consiguiendo áreas de color uniforme cada vez más grandes. Hasta conseguir que todo sea del mismo color... En el vídeo de presentación del juego se entiende mejor. :P

Visualmente es muy bonito, con esa estética "handcrafted" de Lumino City, donde todo parece hecho con papel. Y la música es tranquila y agradable, aunque puede volverse monótona cuando llevas un rato en el mismo puzzle. Aconsejo de nuevo, como con Hexcells, bajar el volumen del juego y ponerte tu propia música.

En las 12h que he jugado he conseguido el 100% del juego, es decir pasarme todos los niveles con el mínimo de movimientos posibles. A eso me ha ayudado ligeramente el sistema de pistas incluido, que te raciona las pistas por días: Tienes un máximo de 10 puntos por día, y la primera pista de un puzzle vale 3 puntos, la segunda 2, y las siguientes 1. Muchas veces, el primer movimiento es suficiente para intuir por donde seguirá la solución. Me parece una idea genial, y bien implementada. 

En conclusión, mientras espero a que acaben su próximo juego, disfrutaré de Lume, la precuela de Lumino City.
Y respecto a este KAMI, totalmente recomendado.

40746825.review:
Ich persönlich habe ca. 13 h gebraucht, um die 100% (alle Puzzles mit perfekt) voll zu machen. Allerdings habe ich auch bei dem ein oder anderen Puzzle die "Hint"-Funktion genutzt. Sonst hätte ich das ein oder andere Puzzle vielleicht auch gar nicht oder zumindest ohne "perfekt" abgeschlossen. 

Spielerisch ist Kami ein Puzzle-Spiel ähnlich wie Lyne (siehe Steam), wobei das Spielziel von Kami jenes ist, dass man alle Felder in einer vorgegebenen Anzahl von Spielzügen in eine einzige Farbe umwandelt. Dabei kann man sogar bei dem ein oder anderen Puzzle die vorgegebene Spielzüge-Vorgabe um 1-2 Züge unterschreiten, sofern man einen effizienteren Lösungsweg als "gedacht" findet. Insofern könnte Kami auch für Hardcore-Puzzlefans interessant sein, wenn es darum geht, die besten Lösungswege auszuloten. 

Persönlich finde ich Kami ein wenig ansprechender als Lyne, weil es sich durch das Farbenspiel und das Umklappen der einzelnen Farbkacheln, welche ja Papier simulieren sollen, einerseits ästhetischer präsentiert und andererseits auch von den Puzzles her etwas abwechslungsreicher gestaltet.
Selbst wenn man ein Puzzle nicht auf Anhieb in der vorgegebenen Anzahl von Zügen löst, ist es doch immer wieder interessant, sich anzuschauen, wie ein Puzzle sich dann in einer einheitlichen Farbe auflöst. Manchmal ergeben sich verschiedene Lösungswege, die in einer anderen Endfarbe enden, was eine kleine Mini-Belohnung darstellt, wenn einem das gefällt. Mir persönlich hat das jedenfalls gefallen.

Kami is a puzzle game that hands you a new set of rules then releases the puzzle-solving kraken you'll eventually become by the time you achieve full completion. The rules are amazingly easy to get the hang of (not to mention this game is super cheap). The soundtrack is peaceful (I've even left it on sometimes just to hear it loop). 

I've personally found myself aiming for perfect completion and it's pretty easy to get absorbed into thinking how best to divide and conquer... but it's also a good game to do casually. If you like puzzle games and just want a small one to leap into every now and then, Kami is the perfect game to get!
